awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Modeling and synthesis for application-specific systems-on-a-chip
awd_abstract_narration:
Popular electronic devices such as e-book readers, automotive entertainment systems, digital TVs, and medical devices, are internally powered by a state-of-the-art computer chip. Such a chip may have hundreds of components, including many microprocessors, graphics processors, video processors, audio processors, memories, and more. Just a few decades ago, so many components would have required a table-sized box, but today they fit on a tiny fingernail-sized chip. Because such a chip costs tens of millions of dollars to build, companies that build these chips make them as configurable as possible, so the same chip that is used in a digital TV application may also be used in a medical device application. However, engineers have a hard time setting all the configurable features to get the chip's performance and power optimal for their specific application. The features are like the ingredients of a recipe; an imperfect balance can ruin the performance/power (or the meal). As a result, today's chips run much slower than they could, get hotter, and consume more battery than they could as well. 

This project's intellectual merit includes developing techniques to automatically tune a state-of-the-art chip's many configurable features to serve any one particular application well, thus substantially improving performance and power for any application implemented on such a chip. The project will develop a unified computation model that ideally supports such techniques, empowering engineers to make best use of state-of-the-art chips. 

The project's broader impacts not only include improving the performance and power of a wide variety of popular devices, but also includes a web-based tool for capturing the unified computation model. Such a tool will positively impact university education as well as practicing engineers, and can catalyze research.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
The project developed cloud-based frameworks for simulating several kinds of embedded systems, to enable engineers to more quickly build and test their software. The project created template software for a commonly-developed category of embedded systems applications known as pattern recognition systems, and showed that using the template enabled engineers to build higher-quality pattern recognition systems in the same or less time. The project created template software known as RIOS to enable engineers to write programs that have multiple tasks running concurrently on a microcontroller, without the need for those engineers to install and use a real-time operating system (RTOS). The project showed that RIOS reduced the time and expertise needed to create multitasking software versus an RTOS, and led to higher-quality software versus previous approaches not using an RTOS. The project developed a cloud-based simulator for a microcontroller, known as RIMS, included a state-machine simulator to support the pulsing/periodic state machine model. The project developed simulation for systems-on-a-chip and used the framework for simulation of various key applications, such as neural networks, self-driving cars, health monitoring, biometric authentication, and machine learning. The project developed techniques to automatically adjust parameters in control systems, using the simulation framework. The project developed techniques to enhance the security of systems-on-a-chip by detecting and preventing side-channel attacks. The project developing synthesis and system-level exploration techniques for precision-timed and time-constrained embedded systems. Some of the work was incorporated into two popular textbooks as well as into university courses. Dozens of graduate students and undergraduate students received training as part of the project. 


 


Last Modified: 09/30/2022
Modified by: Frank Vahid
